bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, October 29, 1875

div1.p: Reed makes a visit to a doctor's family. An army general gives him word on his future assignment.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, October 29, 1875

opener.dateline:
Willet's Point,
New York Harbor,
Octr 29th 75.

div1.p:
You will
see, by the date of this letter, that
I write on Friday, contrary
to my usual custom. Now, do
not proceed, at once, to accuse
me of carelessness, but hear
my reason. Well, here it is.
Wednesday afternoon, when
the steamer, Henry Smith, ar-
rived at Willet's Point, I
received a letter from Dr
Torney, begging me to come
down to Fort Wood, by
return steamer, and spend
the night with him. His little
boy was quite sick, and as
his parental solicitude had
clouded his own judgement,
he was anxious that I should
see the little fellow. Of course,
I made haste to comply, and
5 o'clock found me under
his roof- Fortunately, Master
Torney was not very sick
and I was soon able to dispel
the father's fears. I had the
pleasure of a long conver-
sation with Mrs. T., who
is a very agreeable soul &
improves on acquaintance.
She, by the way, made many
inquiries concerning “Miss
Lawrence”; how I enjoyed
my recent visit; when I
expected to go again; when
I was going to get married,
etc, etc. The Dr & I sat up
till a late hour, talking
over past times, & discussing
the probable chances of fu-
ture promotion, & estimating
the number of Surgeons who
would probably die within
the next twenty years; & other
such innocent amuse-
ments. Leaving the Fort, at
10 o'clock the next morning,
we went to Army Headquar-
ters & had a conversation
with General Cuyler- He told
me that I would be likely
to remain at this Post for
3 or 4 months longer- Still
he did not know positive-
ly- 'Tis a satisfaction to
know even this. Should I
stay as long as Gen. C. in-
timated, I will make every ef-
fort to come to see my own,
darling E.; & should I be
ordered away within this
period, I will try my best
to make a certain little
town lie in my journey's
way, if it be to stop only
for a day. I must see my
little sweetheart before the
Spring returns, or else I
may forget how she looks,
& that would be a misfortune.
Returning from the City, I did
not reach my Post till
evening, & so much fatigued
as to be compelled to forego the pleasure
of writing till this morning-
I hope the foregoing excuse
will be favorably entertained
as I have no better to offer.
The letter, that you hoped
I would never get, arrived,
as you have already learned.
It was a very sweet & ac-
ceptable letter, but since
you desired that it would
be lost on its way, of
course, I cannot appreciate
it as much- Why did you
say, my darling, that you
would enclose a “tiny flower”
in your letter, & then fail to
do so? Was it in order
to excite my curiosity & give
me something to do by search
ing for it? Or did you change
your mind & conclude to
present it to Mr Myrick?
Im am sure, that he deserved
some favor, at your hands,
after having given you
such a pleasant ride &
gathered you so many beau-
tiful flowers, which I had
refused to pluck for you-
'Twas but just that you
should thus reward him,
and I heartily commend your
action- Yet I must confess that
I am sorry that you could
not spare so much as one
little bloossom for me. It would
have been cherished so fondly
& tenderly. But never mind,
my darling, my darling, per-
haps, you know what is best,
&, it may be, that the crumbs
are good enough for me.
I was really charmed to hear
that you were so pleased
with your buggy-ride with Mr M.
'Tis a consolation to know
that you can -- well, I won't
finish the sentence, my little
E, as I forgot what I was go-
ing to say, and I know you
can never decipher it. The
time was when you would
even have enjoyed a ride
with your humble servant,
by your side- Pardon me,
if this smacks of conceit! But
this was in the days gone
by, when you had not heard
any declaration, on my part,
& when you were not so
easily displeased at my
numerous mistakes, or, at
least, were inclined to overlook
them. Well a day! how blind,
how blind, have we been!
“'Twas ever thus,” etc. But enough
of foolishness, for when I turn
back & read what I have written,
so scilly, so false is it, that my
very soul is sickened by it!
Yet, does not “Irony” beget “Irony”?
All joking aside, my own, sweet Emilie,
you did not send me the flower,
for the most thorough search
failed to discover it- Yet I do not
despair of receiving it & shall ex-
pect, at least two in my next-
Have you made the acquaintance
of Miss Peace, as yet? If so, give
me your opinion of the fair
damsel- Perhaps, she can tell you
something of my early career that
you would be interesting- Who knows?
div1.closer: As ever, your fond & devoted Walter.
